docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Along with the concerns raised in ''For the Uninsured, Drug Trials Are Health Care'' (front page, June 22), additional problems result from the practice of encouraging uninsured patients to enroll in drug trials.

headline.main: When Drug Trials Equal Health Care

docs.abstract: Martin Schiffenbauer letter warns that encouraging uninsured patients to enroll in drug trials may skew tests results (S)
docs.snippet: To the Editor:    Along with the concerns raised in ''For the Uninsured, Drug Trials Are Health Care'' (front page, June 22), additional problems result from the practice of encouraging uninsured patients to enroll in drug trials.

docs.lead_paragraph: Following are excerpts from a news conference today by President Clinton, as recorded by the Federal News Service, a private transcription agency: Prepared Remarks Earlier today, in a speech at Georgetown University, I discussed the opportunities now before our nation. Before I take questions, let me just take a moment to recap what I believe is America's agenda in the coming months.

docs.lead_paragraph: Snake oil salesmen have been around for ages. But they are proliferating in the electronic age, according to the Federal Trade Commission, which announced today that it had identified hundreds of Web sites promoting phony cures for 30 ailments, including AIDS, multiple sclerosis, liver disease and cancer. The sites are so numerous, the agency said, that it cannot possibly take action against all of them. But it has reached legal settlements with four Internet companies: one that advertised shark cartilage as a cure for cancer, another that sold a fatty acid to treat arthritis, and two that promoted magnets for various diseases.

headline.main: Trade Agency Finds Web Slippery With Snake Oil

docs.abstract: Federal Trade Commission warns that Web sites promoting phony health cures are proliferating; announces it has identified hundreds of Web sites promoting phony cures for 30 ailments, including AIDS, multiple sclerosis, liver disease and cancer; finds that Web sites are so numerous that it cannot possibly take action against all of them (M)
